Understanding Tasks

Because the application includes a task scheduling component as well as a version control system and defect tracking system, it allows you to link tasks to files or change requests and perform other useful operations. The Task component can also interoperate with Microsoft Project, which makes it even more useful for managing projects.

When you use the Task component by itself, you can determine who should do what and when, estimate the time required to complete work on a task, record how many hours a task actually takes, and compare these times. See the Help section titled Using Tasks in StarTeam for additional information.

Important: Information in the Help system on the Task component explains how to use the standard property dialog to create and edit tasks. Depending upon how your team has set up the application, you may see a totally different dialog called an alternate property editor (APE).

When the Task component interoperates with Microsoft Project, this relationship is strictly defined. See the Help section titled Using Tasks in Microsoft Project for additional information.

Using the StarTeam Task Component and StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration

The following tasks should be done only in the StarTeam Task component:

  • Creating, editing and deleting work records. Work records are used to update the percent completed and other fields in Microsoft Project.

  • Entering data in customized task fields. Custom fields are created with StarTeam and placed on the Custom tab of the Task Properties dialog.

  • Adding attachments.

  • Adding comments for task revisions. When the StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration updates the information in a StarTeam task, a new revision is created, but no comment is added.

The following tasks should be done only in Microsoft Project:

  • Creating tasks and subtasks. You can add tasks in StarTeam, but Microsoft Project will not be aware of them and the work for them will not be recorded in the Microsoft Project file.

  • Assigning task resources.

  • Estimating the time required to complete tasks. These fields are disabled in StarTeam.

  • Moving tasks.

  • Adding notes to a task. This field is disabled in StarTeam.

The following tasks can be performed with either product:

  • Modifying task properties. Many StarTeam task fields are disabled because they are controlled solely by the Microsoft Project Integration. However, users can modify work records and a few other fields from within StarTeam.

  • Deleting tasks. The Microsoft Project Integration deletes StarTeam tasks that are children of other tasks. If the root of a task tree is deleted, the Integration cannot locate it to delete it. You can delete a replicated task and its children from StarTeam, but only if the task is the root of a task tree.)

Using the StarTeam Task Component with or without the StarTeam Microsoft Project Integration

The following operations have no effect on the Microsoft Project Integration, if it is being used. Therefore, they should be performed in the StarTeam Task component:

  • Displaying specific fields in the Task list.

  • Sorting and grouping data in the Task list.

  • Applying queries or filters to the Task list.

  • Marking tasks or task trees read or unread.

  • Searching for tasks or subtasks.

  • Comparing task revisions.

  • Sharing entire task trees with another view (do not share branches alone).

  • Reconfiguring a task or subtask.

  • Viewing task references.

  • Adding a label to a task.

  • Linking tasks to other application items.

  • Assigning access rights.

  • Sending a task via e-mail.

  • Creating reports and charts.

  • Setting personal options for tasks.
